elements.content: In this work, a microporous Pb­(II)-based framework (FJI-H22) has been synthesized upon solvothermal reaction, which is constructed from two kinds of rarely seen tetranuclear Pb­(II) clusters. FJI-H22 has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, when immersed in methanol FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations to form FJI-H22-MeOH. In particular, high stability (stable up to 300 °C in atmosphere), large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (483 m2·g–1), and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to be a good candidate for purification of natural gas. As anticipated, desolvated FJI-H22 can selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydrocarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a microporous Pb(II)-based framework (FJI-H22) has been synthesized upon solvothermal reaction, which is constructed from two kinds of rarely seen tetranuclear Pb(II) clusters. FJI-H22 has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, when immersed in methanol FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations to form FJI-H22-MeOH. In particular, high stability (stable up to 300 °C in atmosphere), large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (483 m2⋅g-1), and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to be a good candidate for purification of natural gas. As anticipated, desolvated FJI-H22 can selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydrocarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.

elements.content: A Pb4-cluster-based framework (FJI-H22), which has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels, can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transitions when immersed in methanol and DMF respectively. In particular, high stability, large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to highly selectively adsorb and separate C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: A Pb4-cluster-based framework (FJI-H22), which has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels, can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transitions when immersed in methanol and DMF respectively. In particular, high stability, large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to highly selectively adsorb and separate C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as one kind of the most active research fields in porous materials, have potential applications in luminescence, drug delivery, and catalysis. Owing to their orderly and tunable pores as well as permanent porosities, they have received much attention especially in the field of gas storage and separation. For example, natural gas, which has been considered as a kind of clean energy source, has wide applications in industry. Natural gas is mainly composed of CH4 accompanied by some light hydrocarbons such as C2H6 and C3H8. In order to efficiently utilize this clean gas, it is of great significance to remove higher hydrocarbons from light CH4. Compared with traditional cost- and energy-consuming cryogenic liquefaction, MOFs have exhibited the potential ability to adsorb and separate light hydrocarbons. On the other hand, recent research mainly focuses on the frameworks based on the transition metal ions and the rare earth ions. In comparison, less attention has been paid to the main group metal ions, especially Pb­(II) cations. As we know, the heavy Pb­(II) ion has lone-pair electrons, a large ionic radius, as well as wide coordination numbers, which promise to provide a better opportunity for the construction of extraordinary frameworks with potential applications in photoluminescence, sensors, photovoltaic conversions, and nonlinear optics. However, only several examples of Pb­(II)-based frameworks can selectively store and separate gases. Moreover, up to now there are few examples of flexible Pb­(II)-based frameworks exhibiting selective adsorption and separation of C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue  on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as one kind of the most active research fields in porous materials, have potential applications in luminescence, drug delivery, and catalysis. Owing to their orderly and tunable pores as well as permanent porosities, they have received much attention especially in the field of gas storage and separation. For example, natural gas, which has been considered as a kind of clean energy source, has wide applications in industry. Natural gas is mainly composed of CH4 accompanied by some light hydrocarbons such as C2H6 and C3H8. In order to efficiently utilize this clean gas, it is of great significance to remove higher hydrocarbons from light CH4. Compared with traditional cost- and energy-consuming cryogenic liquefaction, MOFs have exhibited the potential ability to adsorb and separate light hydrocarbons. On the other hand, recent research mainly focuses on the frameworks based on the transition metal ions and the rare earth ions. In comparison, less attention has been paid to the main group metal ions, especially Pb(II) cations. As we know, the heavy Pb(II) ion has lone-pair electrons, a large ionic radius, as well as wide coordination numbers, which promise to provide a better opportunity for the construction of extraordinary frameworks with potential applications in photoluminescence, sensors, photovoltaic conversions, and nonlinear optics. However, only several examples of Pb(II)-based frameworks can selectively store and separate gases. Moreover, up to now there are few examples of flexible Pb(II)-based frameworks exhibiting selective adsorption and separation of C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4.

elements.content: Herein, we report a microporous framework (FJI-H22) based on rarely seen Pb4 clusters, which has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformations when immersed in methanol and N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) respectively. In particular, high stability, large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydracarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a microporous framework (FJI-H22) based on rarely seen Pb4 clusters, which has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformations when immersed in methanol and N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) respectively. In particular, high stability, large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydracarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.

elements.content: Single crystals of FJI-H22 can be obtained by reaction of a tetracarboxylate linker H4TCAB (H4TCAB = (E)-5′,5′′′′-(diazene-1,2-diyl)­bis­(([1,1′:3′,1′′-terphenyl]-4,4′′-dicarboxylic acid))) and Pb­(NO3)2 in DMF at 120 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that FJI-H22 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group. The asymmetric unit consists of four crystallographically independent Pb­(II) ions, two fully deprotonated TCAB4– ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules, and three free DMF molecules. In the TCAB4– ligands, all the carboxylate groups participate in the coordination spheres of the Pb­(II) cations with three kinds of coordination modes, i.e., μ1: η1η1, μ2: η1η1, and μ2: η1η2 (Figure S1). The Pb–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.33–2.76 Å, which are all comparable to the reported values. However, these two TCAB4– ligands exhibit two kinds of coordination fashions. One TCAB4– ligand coordinates to six Pb­(II) cations, while the other bonds to seven Pb­(II) cations (Figure S2). Regarding the Pb­(II) cations, there are three kinds of coordination environments. Pb4 and Pb2 are in the low three- and four-coordinated modes respectively, while Pb1 and Pb3 are both in the high six-coordinated mode. For these four independent Pb­(II) cations, they form two kinds of Pb4 clusters (a,b). Through the connection of the TCAB4– ligands, these clusters form two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels along the crystallographic b axis (d). The large channel is estimated as ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 Å, while the small one is estimated as ca. 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å. The free DMF molecules exist in the above channels as guests. Additionally, the solvent accessible volume in fully desolvated FJI-H22 is about 33.3%, which is calculated by PLATON.
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of FJI-H22 can be obtained by reaction of a tetracarboxylate linker H4TCAB (H4TCAB = (E)-5',5''''-(diazene-1,2-diyl)bis(([1,1':3',1''-terphenyl]-4,4''-dicarboxylic acid))) and Pb(NO3)2 in DMF at 120 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that FJI-H22 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group. The asymmetric unit consists of four crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, two fully deprotonated TCAB4- ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules, and three free DMF molecules. In the TCAB4- ligands, all the carboxylate groups participate in the coordination spheres of the Pb(II) cations with three kinds of coordination modes, i.e., μ1: η1η1, μ2: η1η1, and μ2: η1η2 (Figure S1). The Pb-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.33-2.76 Å, which are all comparable to the reported values. However, these two TCAB4- ligands exhibit two kinds of coordination fashions. One TCAB4- ligand coordinates to six Pb(II) cations, while the other bonds to seven Pb(II) cations (Figure S2). Regarding the Pb(II) cations, there are three kinds of coordination environments. Pb4 and Pb2 are in the low three- and four-coordinated modes respectively, while Pb1 and Pb3 are both in the high six-coordinated mode. For these four independent Pb(II) cations, they form two kinds of Pb4 clusters (a,b). Through the connection of the TCAB4- ligands, these clusters form two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels along the crystallographic b axis (d). The large channel is estimated as ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 Å, while the small one is estimated as ca. 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å. The free DMF molecules exist in the above channels as guests. Additionally, the solvent accessible volume in fully desolvated FJI-H22 is about 33.3%, which is calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: Structure analyses of FJI-H22. View of two kinds of Pb4 clusters in FJI-H22 (a) and (b). View of the unique Pb4 cluster in FJI-H22-MeOH (c). View of the two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis in FJI-H22 (d) and FJI-H22-MeOH (e) respectively. Symmetric codes: A, −x, 2 – y, 1 – z; B, 1 – x, 2 – y, 2 – z; C, 2 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; D, 2 – x, 3 – y, −z; E, x, 1 + y, z – 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure analyses of FJI-H22. View of two kinds of Pb4 clusters in FJI-H22 (a) and (b). View of the unique Pb4 cluster in FJI-H22-MeOH (c). View of the two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis in FJI-H22 (d) and FJI-H22-MeOH (e) respectively. Symmetric codes: A, -x, 2 - y, 1 - z; B, 1 - x, 2 - y, 2 - z; C, 2 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z; D, 2 - x, 3 - y, -z; E, x, 1 + y, z - 1.

elements.content: To estimate the purity of the synthesized sample, we have carried out powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments. The results show that the experimental spectra are in good agreement with the simulated ones, which demonstrates the good phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S3). To investigate the porosity of the desolvated FJI-H22, we have immersed the synthesized samples in methanol to exchange high-boiling DMF molecules. More surprisingly, we find that the exchanged crystals (FJI-H22-MeOH) can retain the single crystals. Therefore, we have performed the single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment for FJI-H22-MeOH. Interestingly, the results show that FJI-H22-MeOH crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/n space group, which is much different from that of FJI-H22. Compared with FJI-H22, the asymmetric unit of FJI-H22-MeOH consists of two crystallographically independent Pb­(II) ions, one fully deprotonated TCAB4– ligands, one coordinated methanol molecule, and some disordered guest molecules. In addition, the independent Pb­(II) cations are both in the five-coordinated mode. Therefore, there is only one kind of Pb4 cluster in FJI-H22-MeOH (c), which is bridged by the carboxylate groups into one-dimensional chains (Figure S5). As seen in e, there remain two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis. The large channel is estimated as ca. 12.17 Å × 15.53 and 6.06 Å × 11.81 Å respectively, which have slightly changed in comparison to the ones in FJI-H22. At the same time, the solvent accessible volume in FJI-H22-MeOH slightly decreases to 30.1%. Furthermore, if we immersed the FJI-H22-MeOH in DMF, FJI-H22 can be reversely obtained. However, it is a pity that if FJI-H22-MeOH iws immersed in CH2Cl2 the crystals crack into polycrystals, which are not suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses.
elements.clean_text: To estimate the purity of the synthesized sample, we have carried out powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments. The results show that the experimental spectra are in good agreement with the simulated ones, which demonstrates the good phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S3). To investigate the porosity of the desolvated FJI-H22, we have immersed the synthesized samples in methanol to exchange high-boiling DMF molecules. More surprisingly, we find that the exchanged crystals (FJI-H22-MeOH) can retain the single crystals. Therefore, we have performed the single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment for FJI-H22-MeOH. Interestingly, the results show that FJI-H22-MeOH crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/n space group, which is much different from that of FJI-H22. Compared with FJI-H22, the asymmetric unit of FJI-H22-MeOH consists of two crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, one fully deprotonated TCAB4- ligands, one coordinated methanol molecule, and some disordered guest molecules. In addition, the independent Pb(II) cations are both in the five-coordinated mode. Therefore, there is only one kind of Pb4 cluster in FJI-H22-MeOH (c), which is bridged by the carboxylate groups into one-dimensional chains (Figure S5). As seen in e, there remain two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis. The large channel is estimated as ca. 12.17 Å × 15.53 and 6.06 Å × 11.81 Å respectively, which have slightly changed in comparison to the ones in FJI-H22. At the same time, the solvent accessible volume in FJI-H22-MeOH slightly decreases to 30.1%. Furthermore, if we immersed the FJI-H22-MeOH in DMF, FJI-H22 can be reversely obtained. However, it is a pity that if FJI-H22-MeOH iws immersed in CH2Cl2 the crystals crack into polycrystals, which are not suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses.

elements.content: To obtain the fully desolvated FJI-H22 (FJI-H22-desolvated), the synthesized sample was soaked in MeOH for 3 days and then CH2Cl2 for 3 days. Then, the sample was heated at 80 °C for 10 h in a dynamic high vacuum. The PXRD of the activated samples is in good agreement with the simulated ones of FJI-H22-MeOH, indicating that the desolvated samples retain the framework integrity (Figure S6). In addition, the high stability of FJI-H22 also can be demonstrated by the thermal stability test, which is stable up to 300 °C in atmosphere (Figure S7). To investigate the permanent porosity of FJI-H22-desolvated, the N2 adsorption isotherm is performed at 77 K and 1 bar (). The N2 adsorption isotherm shows a classical type-I adsorption behavior with maximal adsorption capacity of 135.9 cm3·g–1, indicating the microporous nature of FJI-H22-desolvated. The calculated BET surface area is 483 m2·g–1, which is comparable to the highest values of the Pb­(II)-based MOFs. More interestingly, FJI-H22-desolvated exhibits good abilities for selective storage of light hydrocarbons. Single-component sorption isotherms are performed at 273 and 298 K with the pressure up to 1 bar. The experiments reveal that the uptake amounts of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 at ambient condition (298 K, 1 bar) are 58.27, 41.46, 44.55, 63.87, 53.48, and 48.24 cm3·g–1, respectively (a,b). It must be noted that the sorption capacity of FJI-H22-desolvated for C2–C3 hydrocarbons is higher than those of ZJNU-62, which was the only one lead organic framework for selective storage of C2 hydrocarbons in previous reports. When the temperature is lowered to 273 K, the uptake values of C2H2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 increase to 72.56, 58.68, 57.76, 71.92, 58.33, and 54.85 cm3·g–1, respectively (c,d). In comparison, the CH4 adsorption amounts are only 7.60 cm3·g–1 and 14.18 cm3·g–1 at 273 and 298 K respectively, which are much less than those of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons at the same conditions. More interestingly, FJI-H22-desolvated saturates with C3 hydrocarbons at lower pressures, and the slopes of adsorption isotherms are much steeper than that of CH4, indicating the stronger affinity between higher hydrocarbons and the pore surfaces. Such great difference in adsorption amounts and the interactions between higher hydrocarbons and CH4 indicates that FJI-H22-desolvated may realize highly selective separations of CH4 from C3 hydrocarbons.

elements.content: N2 isotherms of FJI-H22-desolvated at 77 K and 1 bar.
elements.clean_text: 2  N2 isotherms of FJI-H22-desolvated at 77 K and 1 bar.

elements.content: Sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C2 hydrocarbons at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. The sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C3 hydrocarbons at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  Sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C2 hydrocarbons at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. The sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C3 hydrocarbons at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.

elements.content: In consideration of the large difference in adsorption amounts between C2 or C3 hydrocarbons and CH4, IAST is used to predict the selectivity of binary mixtures of C2 or C3 hydrocarbons with CH4 (molar ratios: 50:50) at 298 and 273 K respectively. At 298 K and 1 bar, the calculated selectivities of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C2H6/CH4, C3H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 14.68, 8.86, 11.95, 297.29, 245.46, 145.23, respectively (a,b). When the temperature decreases to 273 K, the IAST predicted selectivities of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C2H6/CH4, C3H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 (0.5:0.5) slightly increase to 17.65, 9.38, 13.32, 6317.94, 421.87, and 199.02, respectively (c,d). It should be noted that the selectivities of FJI-H22-desolvated for C2H6/CH4 at 298 K are similar to those of UTSA-35a and PCN-224, and are higher than the corresponding values of UPC-33, JLU-Liu51,and JLU-Liu37. To our best knowledge, the selectivity of C3H8/CH4 is higher than the corresponding values of UPC-33, JLU-Liu5, USTA-35a, and InOF-1.

At 298 K and 1 bar, the calculated selectivities of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C2H6/CH4, C3H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 14.68, 8.86, 11.95, 297.29, 245.46, 145.23, respectively (a,b). When the temperature decreases to 273 K, the IAST predicted selectivities of C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, C2H6/CH4, C3H4/CH4, C3H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 (0.5:0.5) slightly increase to 17.65, 9.38, 13.32, 6317.94, 421.87, and 199.02, respectively (c,d). It should be noted that the selectivities of FJI-H22-desolvated for C2H6/CH4 at 298 K are similar to those of UTSA-35a and PCN-224, and are higher than the corresponding values of UPC-33, JLU-Liu51,and JLU-Liu37. To our best knowledge, the selectivity of C3H8/CH4 is higher than the corresponding values of UPC-33, JLU-Liu5, USTA-35a, and InOF-1.

elements.content: Selectivities predicted by IAST for C2 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. Selectivities predicted by IAST for C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.
elements.clean_text: 4  Selectivities predicted by IAST for C2 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. Selectivities predicted by IAST for C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.

elements.content: In addition, we also investigate the potential applications of FJI-H22 for CO2 capture and separation. As shown in Figure S10, CO2, CH4, and N2 uptake are 60.41, 14.18, and 7.37 cm3·g–1 at 273 K, 1 bar, respectively, and 30.45, 7.60, and 2.14 cm3·g–1 at 298 K, 1 bar, respectively. The CO2 uptake is nearly 4 times larger than that of CH4, and the N2 uptake is even lower than that of CH4. The significant differences in the adsorption of CO2, CH4, and N2 at the same condition motivated us to explore the selectivities of CO2/CH4 (0.5:0.5) and CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85). The IAST predicated selectivities of CO2/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 3.50 and 4.18 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. FJI-H22 achieves the IAST value of 20.04 and 16.20 for CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85) at 273 and 298 K, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In addition, we also investigate the potential applications of FJI-H22 for CO2 capture and separation. As shown in Figure S10, CO2, CH4, and N2 uptake are 60.41, 14.18, and 7.37 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K, 1 bar, respectively, and 30.45, 7.60, and 2.14 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K, 1 bar, respectively. The CO2 uptake is nearly 4 times larger than that of CH4, and the N2 uptake is even lower than that of CH4. The significant differences in the adsorption of CO2, CH4, and N2 at the same condition motivated us to explore the selectivities of CO2/CH4 (0.5:0.5) and CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85). The IAST predicated selectivities of CO2/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 3.50 and 4.18 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. FJI-H22 achieves the IAST value of 20.04 and 16.20 for CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85) at 273 and 298 K, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, a Pb4-cluster-based framework FJI-H22 has been synthesized upon solvothermal reaction, which has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels. Interestingly, FJI-H22 can undergo reverse SCSC transformations when immersed in methanol and DMF respectively, which is rarely seen in Pb­(II)-based frameworks. In particular, high stability, large BET surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to highly selectively adsorb and separate C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. On the whole, FJI-H22 represents a rare Pb­(II)-based framework with the potential for purification of natural gas. In addition, we think the above results will shed light on designed syntheses of stable frameworks for gas storage and separation. Further investigation is ongoing.

In particular, high stability, large BET surface area, and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to highly selectively adsorb and separate C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. On the whole, FJI-H22 represents a rare Pb(II)-based framework with the potential for purification of natural gas. In addition, we think the above results will shed light on designed syntheses of stable frameworks for gas storage and separation. Further investigation is ongoing.

cln_elements.content: In this work, a microporous Pb­(II)-based framework (FJI-H22) has been synthesized upon solvothermal reaction, which is constructed from two kinds of rarely seen tetranuclear Pb­(II) clusters. FJI-H22 has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, when immersed in methanol FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations to form FJI-H22-MeOH. In particular, high stability (stable up to 300 °C in atmosphere), large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (483 m2·g–1), and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to be a good candidate for purification of natural gas. As anticipated, desolvated FJI-H22 can selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydrocarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.
cln_elements.clean_text: In this work, a microporous Pb(II)-based framework (FJI-H22) has been synthesized upon solvothermal reaction, which is constructed from two kinds of rarely seen tetranuclear Pb(II) clusters. FJI-H22 has two kinds of one-dimensional microporous channels (ca. 12.80 Å × 15.08 and 6.05 Å × 11.83 Å) along the crystallographic b axis. Interestingly, when immersed in methanol FJI-H22 can undergo reverse single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations to form FJI-H22-MeOH. In particular, high stability (stable up to 300 °C in atmosphere), large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (483 m2⋅g-1), and the nature of microporosity enable desolvated FJI-H22 to be a good candidate for purification of natural gas. As anticipated, desolvated FJI-H22 can selectively adsorb C2/C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, ideal adsorbed solution theory calculations reveal that FJI-H22 shows highly selective separation of higher hydrocarbons over CH4 under ambient conditions.

cln_elements.content: Structure analyses of FJI-H22. View of two kinds of Pb4 clusters in FJI-H22 (a) and (b). View of the unique Pb4 cluster in FJI-H22-MeOH (c). View of the two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis in FJI-H22 (d) and FJI-H22-MeOH (e) respectively. Symmetric codes: A, −x, 2 – y, 1 – z; B, 1 – x, 2 – y, 2 – z; C, 2 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; D, 2 – x, 3 – y, −z; E, x, 1 + y, z – 1.

View of the two kinds of one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic b axis in FJI-H22 (d) and FJI-H22-MeOH (e) respectively. Symmetric codes: A, -x, 2 - y, 1 - z; B, 1 - x, 2 - y, 2 - z; C, 2 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z; D, 2 - x, 3 - y, -z; E, x, 1 + y, z - 1.

cln_elements.content: N2 isotherms of FJI-H22-desolvated at 77 K and 1 bar.

cln_elements.content: Sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C2 hydrocarbons at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. The sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C3 hydrocarbons at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C2 hydrocarbons at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. The sorption isotherms of desolvated FJI-H22 for C3 hydrocarbons at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.

cln_elements.content: Selectivities predicted by IAST for C2 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (a) and 273 K (c) respectively. Selectivities predicted by IAST for C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) gas mixture at 298 K (b) and 273 K (d) respectively.

metadata.title: Flexible Microporous Framework Based on Pb4 Clusters for Highly Selective Storage and Separation of Energy Gases
